friend_mood: feeling afraid because my friend had been looking at pictures of car crashes. Now, she is afraid to drive anywhere. Seriously, she can hardly go anywhere a car might be.
your_strategy: sharing or relating to own experience, expressing care or concern
history:
friend: I have been looking at pictures of crazy car crashes.
me: Oh really? Any interesting ones?
friend: Seriously now I can't drive anywhere. I can't even leave the house for fear of car crash
me: Hey, I'm here for you. Don't worry, accidents are really rare. You're safe.
friend: Thanks for trying to calm me down, but I just can't shake this off.
me: Well, I have a friend who had a similar experience as you. She was also scared to drive after seeing some horrible crashes. But then she realized that most accidents happen when people are not paying attention. So she started to drive more carefully, and now she feels much safer. Maybe you can try to focus on the positive side of driving, instead of dwelling on the negative ones.
friend: Hmm, maybe you're right. I'll try to focus on driving safely. Thanks for the advice!
me: Of course

Nobody's perfect is an idiom that means everyone has flaws and makes mistakes. It is often used to acknowledge that someone is not perfect, but their efforts or actions are still appreciated or valued.

Here are some examples of how "nobody's perfect" can be used in conversation:

* "I know you worked hard on this project, but nobody's perfect. There will always be room for improvement."
* "Don't be too hard on yourself. Nobody's perfect, and we all make mistakes sometimes
